thread.title: Maryland falls to Penn State 31-30 in Locksley's debut
thread.title_full: Maryland falls to Penn State 31-30 in Locksley's debut

title: Maryland falls to Penn State 31-30 in Locksley's debut
text:
(Photo: The Associated Press)
1 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE COLLEGE PARK, Md. (AP) — Following his first game as Maryland's interim coach, Mike Locksley lamented his team's five turnovers and its inability to win a tight contest.
Given everything that preceded Saturday's 31-30 loss to Penn State, keeping it close was an improvement.
Locksley was promoted from offensive coordinator to interim coach on Oct. 11 after Randy Edsall was fired in the wake of three straight losses by a combined 122-34 score.
In his debut, Locksley got everything he asked from the Terrapins in terms of effort. Unfortunately, three interceptions and two lost fumbles — along with a porous pass defense — were too much to overcome.
"The mark of a good team is one that doesn't beat itself, and we did just that," Locksley lamented.
The Terps couldn't finish, either, despite taking a lead into the fourth quarter.
"Good teams find a way to win these games," Locksley said.
Maryland (2-5, 0-3 Big Ten) gave Penn State (6-2, 3-1) all it could handle. But that was of little consolation to Locksley, who said: "We're way beyond moral victories."
He added, "What I did tell them is, 'If you can come in that locker room after a game like today and look yourself in the mirror and know that you did everything you could possibly do to win that ball game, then the scoreboard won't define you.'"
Maryland quarterback Perry Hills ran for 124 yards and went 19 for 28 for 225 yards and a touchdown. But he threw three interceptions and lost two fumbles.
"We were moving the ball pretty well today," Hills said, "but things happen."
Christian Hackenberg went 13 for 29 for 315 yards to help Penn State improve to 36-2-1 against the Terrapins. Chris Godwin had four catches for 135 yards and DaeSean Hamilton totaled 96 yards on his five receptions.
Hackenberg, a 6-foot-4 junior, became the school career leader in completions (608) and yards passing (7,453), displacing Zach Mills in both categories.
Penn State went up 31-27 with 13:39 left when Hackenberg tossed a 27-yard touchdown pass to Geno Lewis.
Maryland cut the gap with a field goal, and then recovered a fumble on the ensuing kickoff. But Hills fumbled it back as he was hit while throwing.
The Terrapins got the ball following a missed field goal try. Locksley opted to go for it on fourth-and-2 from the Maryland 36, and Hills was intercepted by Trevor Williams with 7:51 to go.
Maryland had one turnover left, and it sealed the defeat. After the Terps took over at their own 25, Hills had a pass bounce off the arm of his receiver into the hands of Malik Golden with 1:15 remaining.
"He made some plays in the passing game and he made some plays with his feet," Locksley said of Hills. "Where he can improve starts with his decision making in the passing game."
The Terrapins wore throwback uniforms patterned after the 1961 team. That was the year in which Maryland earned its lone win over the Nittany Lions at home.
For a while, it appeared as if that 44-year drought would end.
Maryland moved 68 yards on its first possession of the third quarter to take a 20-17 lead. After Hills ran 36 yards to the 10, Brandon Ross scored on third down.
Hackenberg responded by completing a pass to Godwin for 31 yards, then throwing a 20-yarder to Hamilton for a touchdown. Both passes were put up for grabs, and on both occasions the receiver made the play.
The back-and-forth duel extended into the next drive, when Hills directed an 88-yard march that ended with a 10-yard touchdown pass to DeAndre Lane, making it 27-24.
That laid the groundwork for an intense fourth quarter.
Penn State led 17-13 at halftime despite being limited to 15 yards rushing and converting only once on third down.
Hackenberg went 7 for 16 before intermission, but his completions went for 196 yards — including a 37-yarder to Godwin, who made an outstanding one-handed catch in the end zone while his defender was being called for pass interference.
Maryland led 13-7 in the second quarter despite committing two turnovers inside the Penn State 20.
___
